title: Before 1 July 2017, will any other European Union (EU) member state set a date for a referendum on leaving the EU?
preds: EU countries with a strong 'leave' contingent are waiting for the conclusion of the UK EU exit negotiations to see what sort of a deal can be struck by a former member  leaving the EU.
Extremely short timescale and unlikely to occur anyway until the outcome of negotiations of the EU member states and the UK, which will set a reasonably clear precedent and baseline.
Nothing has a 0 percent probability, but this comes close. Still 0% if we round down.
Late to the party on this one

With only 3 weeks left till the end of this date and very little buzz around anyone else leaving I think there is no chance something so concrete happening. All those nations currently euro skeptic are not really gearing up in that way. I suspect this question was set up with le Penn on mind or the Dutch euro skeptic party. All the other nations that are poopooing the EU that are inside are feeding off the EU teet (I.E. Greece) so it seems unlikely they will leave
No indication for such a referendum whatsoever

France's recent election of Marcon has quashed such notions for a time. Individuals in other EU states who want to leave will have to wait for a more opportune political climate. They know nationalistic fervor will continue to increase. It's just not strong enough... yet.

Dropping from 2 to zero now that Le Pen has lost. Orban in Hungary doesn't look like he wants to pick a fight with the EU, much less call a referendum. Maybe PiS in Poland (I forget the prime minister and the shadow leader and don't feel like looking them up) will call a referendum but I think they are too busy dealing with rising unhappiness in the country.
The French election result makes this very unlikely.

Even if Le Pen gets elected, she has signaled that she wouldn't rush anything before the end of the summer (besides, EU membership, the Euro etc. are the most controversial topics within her own party - let alone public opinion)
Marine Le Pen stated she would seek negotiations first, before "letting the people decide". I think this eliminates the only outside chance for another referendum in this time frame.
Up 1% on uncertainty related to what might transpire in France.

1) The only one in danger of doing this is France.
2) Marine Le Pen would have to win France's presidential election.
3) This probably will not happen, unless...
     a) there is another major terrorist attack in France, 
     b) Macron is caught up in a scandal (possible with Russia attempting to influence their election), or...
     c) Le Pen finds a billion dollars to outspend Macron (also possible with the help of Russian banks).
4) Le Pen wants to try to negotiate a leave agreement before a referendum. The EU won't do that, but she'll try anyway. This would push back any referendum attempts.
5) If Le Pen went ahead, she'd have to fight her entire government to get a referendum date set by July.
Likely zero with current layout of France's run off election. Unless there's unexpected turn of events in some country out of left field.
-1 for time passing, and no news I can see of any plausible event that would lead to a referendum.
Up 4% on the chance that the situation related to Hungary might evolve in interesting ways.
With article 50 having just been triggered it's likely the other member states that could consider it will wait and see for a few months before making any strong moves.
Closing in on the the date. Reduced from 20 to 10%

The potential candidates to leave are net beneficiaries of EU funds (ie Southern and Eastern European Countries) and the political state (elections) in major EU nations as well as Brexit makes 'see what happens' an attractive option.

Wilders is out of the picture. He is not going to be prime minister. So this leaves only Le Pen as a candidate for calling such a referendum. Regardless of her prospects of winning,  she lately has said that  she would hold a referendum on leaving the EU and the single currency within six months of becoming president. 
This looks kinda hasty. I think the probability of holding a referendum in the first two months is less than 10%. The probability to win the election is currently 30%. So the overall probability is no more than  3%.

I suspect event this is more likely than the current 5% aggregate on here. My own primitive estimates suggest there is a 60% and 75% chance of Le Pen and Wilders winning. Should either of these occur, I would think it 50% likely that either would set a date for an EU referendum before Q3. This is very crude and I am puzzled why the current aggregate here is so low. Doing the sums this is [0.15*0.5 + 0.30*0.5 + 0.45*0.75] = 56%. I suspect I may be missing some facts in my analysis.

A Le Pen victory could trigger one in France *or* somewhere else, but the timing is off. I have estimated 42% for Le Pen win in 2nd round, but runoff is 7 May,  so no way a referendum could be conclusively decided in just three weeks after that.  I say 0% for France. 
No suitable elections coming up elsewhere, and no real emergencies that would be likely to trigger one, except maybe Italy once again. Base rate for surprise elections seems to be less than 1/year in EU, and it would need to occur before end April to be in time (four months from now). Probability of such an election is 1/3, probability of end result being referendum is 1/3 --> base rate 11%. This will start dropping rapidly.

I am just a simple algorithm. On each question, Iook at those players whom I follow, and copy the forecast of one of the several who have made the most recent forecasts. I only use my own judgment when deciding which one to follow if several have made recent forecasts.

For this to happen, a change of government would have to occur. However, the only possible elections leading to such a referendum are the Netherlands (March) and France (April-May). The probability of a strong populist/right-wing government coming to power multiplied by the probability of such a referendum being called within a couple of months is very slim. There is also the possibility of referendums on demand, as possible in the Netherlands. These referendums are not binding but are a real possibility. They are unlikely to be called before the elections as well, however.

I found a list of the top 10 EU member states most likely to do this:
France:  LePen pledges to hold a  referendum if elected Pres, but her chances of being elected look slim
Netherlands:  Party for Freedom pledges EU membership will be a key election issue--that's a far cry from a referendum
Holland:  88% in a recent poll want a referendum, but none is scheduled
Austria:  a former candidate is calling for one in a year, but anyone can call for anything; nothing seems to be happening
Poland:  PiS leader says there is a need for a new European treaty, but hasn't proposed one.
Sweden:  a MEP says that Sweden should consider joining Denmark & the UK, outside of the EU.  So far this is just talk.
Denmark:  held a referendum last December declaring no more power will be ceded to the EU.  No plans for a referendum.
Hungary: PM Orban says Europe needs to change its ways, but has not made any proposals for change.
Italy:  An opposition party with 4% support plans to start a petition to schedule a referendum.

The trouble that the UK is going to have leaving the EU in some acceptable fashion is ever more likely to put off other countries that might consider it. Some Brexiteers have mooted leaving the EU and joining the EFTA, in order to maintain trade relationships. All the EFTA countries have veto rights on membership, and Norway isn't having any of it: http://www.businessinsider.com/brexit-article-50-theresa-may-britain-2016-8. The actual mechanics of leaving are enormously complicated, and will be difficult to engineer, even for the UK, which has a large and capable bureaucracy, let alone countries whose governments aren't quite stable. (https://flipchartfairytales.wordpress.com/2016/08/10/brexit-enough-david-brent-this-is-serious/) And for the lighter side: http://www.politics.co.uk/blogs/2016/07/14/everything-you-need-to-know-about-theresa-may-s-brexit

No other EU member state is currently governed by a party which wishes to leave the EU.  The only country due to complete an election before July 2017, where a party planning to hold an In/Out EU referendum is said to have a chance of winning, is France (the National Front in the French presidential election). There chance of winning is said to be low, and, even if they do, they have said that they will try to negotiate a better deal with the EU and only if they fail would they hold the referendum.  There is thus an extremely small chance that a referendum date could be set in France before 1 July 2017.

The countries with leaders calling to leave the EU after Brexit include France (Marine Le Pen), Netherlands (Geert Wilders), Italy (Mateo Salvini), Sweden and Denmark (Kristian Thulesen Dahl).  The initial impact of Brexit will weaken any efforts for the time being.  Most of the leaders behind the call to leave the EU are looking to take advantage of the momentum created to promote the nationalistic, conservative platforms. Being that the UK has not even yet activated article 50, that momentum will take a while to pick up steam.  A Trump win in the USA might be one factor to propel them but right now, none seem to have gotten enough support.

Within EU member states, exiting the EU is a cause with interesting potential for politically ambitious people both inside and outside the political mainstream seeking to gain traction with the media and electorate. The European political landscape is conducive to additional exit activity and could get to the point of at least one additional member state scheduling an exit vote because: 
1. "Leave" proponents within the UK Conservative party emerged with important new assignments, which can be seen by politically ambitious people elsewhere as validating the proposition that they could be similarly advantaged if they come to the forefront of an exit campaign.
2 . UKIP has proved unable to collect post-referendum political dividends from the UK vote, but politically ambitious people elsewhere can still infer that (a) UKIP and its leaders came far even if they haven't obtained benefits commensurate with the success of their cause, and (b) UKIP's failure to capitalize on the Leave victory is a lesson in how not to do it rather than a sign that such benefits are unattainable.
3. Donald Trump's momentum in the US (and his endorsement of Brexit) offers further encouragement that nationalist, iconoclastic politics are viable. Even if Trump fails to win the general election, politically ambitious people in Europe will still tend to interpret his rise as testifying to the potency of this brand of politics.
4. Further, Donald Trump's success demonstrates that logical concerns about post-election consequences, such as the difficult choices now facing the UK, have limited impact on voters wishing to cast an "in your eye" protest vote.
5. Over the next year developments in the pre/early stages of the UK's Article 50 negotiations are 65% likely to encourage exit elsewhere because in the  view of Eurosceptics (a) if EU leaders appear accommodative this will reduce the basis for fears of post-exit costs, and (b) if EU leaders appear vindictive and punitive this will aggravate resentment towards Brussels and fuel support for protest.
6. Polling in multiple EU member states shows at least significant minority support for EU exit.
7. General elections in 2016 and 2017 will provide openings for escalating the debate over continued EU membership, e.g., Austria, France, Germany, Netherlands.
8, Developments of the sort that feed exit support are an important prerequisite for getting as far as setting a date for a referendum in the next year. There is 75% potential for one or more such developments in Europe: euro crisis; banking/sovereign debt crisis; recession in Europe; surge of immigrants from the Mideast; increase in terrorist acts by Mideast immigrants.
Taking into account Sevedb's comment about chances of Anti Eu parties winning elections next 6 months:
Several places have suggested it - as the consequences of Brexit become more concrete, it's likely those suggestions will gather steam

The string of terrorist attacks in Germany after the cases in France will increase nationalist sentiment and strengthen the pushback against the central system. However, calling a referendum is still up to the parliaments of the countries in the EU and unless a clearly anti-EU party wins this won't happen. There are very few elections happening before July 2017 and in none an anti-EU party seems set to win big.

It will probably be another referendum in the future, as the construction of the EU is facing increasing centrifuagl forces. However the brexit recesion and the uncertanies on the economic results will, in my opinion, delay these initiatives.

I think Brexit taught many lessons and it will teach even more about leaving EU. It spurred more thinking  about consequences of anti EU referendums. This was also a chance to educate largely ignorant EU public about the benefits of belonging to EU. I think this was the high water of anti-EU sentiments.

Two issues.  1) EU member states will watch what happens to the UK, checking out advantages, disadvantages, turmoil, etc.  2) Most (19 of the 28 member states) are also in the Euro, and I would think that would increase the pain of leaving the EU.

I agree with liberto that other EU countries will wait to see what happens to Brexit. France and Netherlands have groups who would like a Frexit or a Nexit, but both are also in the Euro, which makes leaving the EU doubly complicated. When interviewed both Le Pen (France) and Wilder (Netherlands) seemed to assume "leaving the EU" would be into a relationship with the EU similar Norway. My expectation is that between now and 1 July 2017 the wisdom of Brexit will become questioned more and more. Its quite possible that there will be no noticeable progress on negotiations between the EU and UK by then, but lots of groups of people in the UK will have realised that each of the specific forms of Brexit possible (e.g. soft or hard as defined by the Economist) each bring big disadvantages and there could be increasing calls to scrap Brexit.
Existing governments won't call for a referendum without first having a general election

Leaving the EU would be a disaster for the leaving country. The fall of the GBP and struggles with EU shows that it would be a bad move. I do not think that any right wing party in the EU is strong enough to achieve a successful leave.
Other EU national leaders will want to see what happens in the UK-EU negotiations before they call a referendum in their own country.
Not only there is "set a date", but also "for a referendum" of all other possible EU-exit means e.g. an executive order or a parliamentary vote.

The likelihood is that a country will wait the outcome of the process of "Brexit" before considering a referendum. The possibility exists, however, that a victory for FN in France in the 2017 elections may trigger another referendum in FR.

Since the UK Tory won general election in May 2015, it took Cameron 10 months to announce the referendum date.
That means any EU members will have to bring the referendum topic on table this year before setting a date by July 2017.

Given the year timeframe outlined by the questions, I believe there is a very high probability that more withdrawals may follow within the time frame. My immediate picks are 1) Scotland followed by 2) Northern Ireland.
Scotland already has a buildup of ill will and a framework in place for withdrawal. The Scots' decision to remain a part of the UK following the 2014 referendum was based heavily upon the ideal of maintaining a healthy trade relationship with Europe. England's growing nationalism and subsequent withdrawal from the EU may be perceived, at best, as a direct threat to the Scots' economic interests; at worst, it may cause them to re-evaluate their decision to remain a part of the UK, thus triggering another voter referendum. David Cameron's exit from the PM seat can only aggravate the situation. Cameron's personal reassurances appeared to play a significant role in keeping proud Scots in the fold. Without power to enforce change, it is hard to believe that Cameron's reassurances, if offered, would be met with much credulity. In the end, I strongly believe that the Scots will seize the opportunity to launch another attempt at withdrawal. In my mind, question isn't if, but when the Scots will brave another go. I expect Northern Ireland, desirous of change, will nonetheless take their cue from their Scottish neighbors; I suspect they will wait and watch, as the new PM is seated and act later rather than sooner.
The countries most likely to want to leave the EU are the paying countries. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budget_of_the_European_Union
After the plunge in stock market and plunge in pound, I don't see anyone looking at the prospect of leaving the union as something favorable.
There are rumblings but given the fiasco that is Brexit, these are unlikely to morph into formal processess any time soon.

With the help of a spreadsheet, listed all current 27 EU member states, except the UK. 
Assumed that it is rather unlikely that the current respective governments would trigger a referendum before 01 July 2017.   
Checked/estimated the forthcoming election dates for each EU member state. 
For each nation, estimated the chance of a pro EU Exit party winning power / government. 
Subsequently, estimated the chance of each EU member state government setting (before 01 July 2017) a referendum date. 
Currently getting 64%.
Everyone will see the economic implications -amply demonstrated by the UK

England will negotiate a smooth exit from the EU, because both Parties must have orderly transition or face dire consequences. Other EU members will see that EU will capitulate and follow UK out the door, main driver will be continued rise of right wing politics a la La Pen, most likely Finland.
Several countries have already stated that they are considering leaving.
EU leaders will do everything in their power to resist such calls, and there is no EU member country where the dominant political party has an appetite for such a contest.

less than 1 month after the Brexit vote - things have settled down. Events such as Turkey, Nice and the general discontent with status quo give this a reasonable chance. With all the upcoming elections this bears watching

While low, I would say that the chances are at an all time high for various reasons. Immigration in certain EU member states is under serious pressure, and the threat of charging them for not taking refugees would out weight the gains lesser states receive (e.g - Poland). Other states are under severe pressure for opposition anti eu austerity (Spain/Greece). Still all of these nations are not major players in the grand scheme of things, and have a tendency to back down to the EU. More will be known as major players elections come up (e.g- French), and what happens to the EU with growth in general over the next 6-10 mos.
Brexit seemingly negative consequences will deter others for now.

No. Europe is already in enough turmoil, with the UK leaving, an attempted coup in Turkey on the EU's border, terrorism attacks in France and asylum migration from North African states. EU leaders will be keen to keep the EU together, so are unlikely to offer a referendum that might trigger another Leave.

I think the political has been sufficiently scared by the UK outcome, and they will resist the idea in their home country. An election may reverse that, but requires a radical election outcome and enough political control and stability to set a referendum within a year of now.

Brexit will bring difficulties to Britain and more important to British expatriates in the EU. As Greece's difficulties imposed by the far left deterred other far left parties to haveâ€‹ any real success so will Brexit.
Countries such as The Netherlands and Austria may want to consider leaving

Staying low for now as I think most parties will wait until the fallout from Brexit is better understood. Also doubtful that a referendum date could be finalized within a year - it took Cameron's Britain more than two years of negotiations before the June Brexit poll was formally announced. 
On the other hand: Migrant crisis not going away; widespread dissatisfaction with EU leadership; questions over viability of Schengen and the euro; rise of right-wing populism; terrorism. We've already seen that there are visceral reasons for wanting out, so, all logic aside, a tipping point may not be far off.

I believe a second member state WILL hold a referendum on leaving the EU in the near future. But 1st July 2017 is very soon. A Eurosceptic party would have to both take power and then set the date for the referendum, all within a year from now. Not gonna happen.

I'll go with the reasoning that for Eurozone countries this is unlikely within one year frame for couple reasons: high costs, uncertainty of how to disentangle from Euro. Also a pro-exit party would have to win elections and schedule referendum immediately. Although some pro-exit parties may do better in coming elections (note: look through election calendar before July 2017), it is unlikely any of them will outright win. I think it is very unlikely that any pro-EU party would schedule such referendum after Brexit debacle. Potential risks are Greece and economy shock/downturn in some other country (Italy? - I think this is unlikely, but I might be wrong). I think risks are low.
Italy is on a really tuff situation and if they don't get a bailout from the EU they would have to consider other options
After seeing — and living through — the upcoming travails of Britain, none of the others will want to experience it.

1 July 2017 is too early for that. Even if proponents of such actions win politically in other countries, they would want to see the economic impact of Brexit first and the discussions between the UK and EU. Besides, for a country in the euro area, the costs of such an action are very high.
No other country will ask to leave the EU before July 2017
I think Portugal will be the next country to plan on leaving the European Union disaster.
Very unlikely by 7/1/17.  Others perhaps inclined will wait to see what happens with the UK exit.

Very unlikely. Only possibility I can think of is a National Front victory in the French presidential elections May 2017, but it's highly unlikely that they would set a date so soon, even if they did win, which itself is unlikely.
Extremely unlikely, fall out of Brexit not fully known, no other country will risk setting a date with the next year.

Not likely.  Too many people now realize that Britian has turned its back on a good deal.  Their vote to leave has given pause to the notion that even a strong economy can thrive without the EU.  Other EU countries are closely watching for example the potential demise of Tata Steel in the UK and it's probable impact on British blue collar workers.
1. Other countries will be cautious to see the consequences of BREXIT; 2. EU will respond to protect itself by some kind of populist reform.
Austria and the Netherlands will. The refugees in Europe will commit another mass rape over Christmas which will force the more right wing governments to do this.
This is a conditional prediction with 3 relevant factors.

Not as unlikely as people are claiming. Far-right parties on the rise in Austria, Netherlands, etc. Problem IMO comes from rather late Dutch elections (March) which mean that even if PVV win, may not have enough time to call it.
There are elections in Austria, France, Germany over the next year. Greece is still on the brink. Some leader may be firced over the next year to 'offer' a referendum to keep a party together

Agree that the number of hurdles to go through make it unlikely that a date will be set by 1st July. But my estimate is increased a little by the fact that those hoping for independence might want to rush the process so Scotland doesn't have to start the process of leaving the EU only to rejoin.

It is uncertain whether the UK will actually leave the EU and no other country has made as much noise about leaving.  Any other government thinking of leaving the EU will likely wait to see how Brexit progresses before starting to convince their own people that a referendum is necessary.
Oh sh&%. Gotta increase for Frexit and Nexit on the sad, sad news from Nice. More than 70 dead and over 100 injured. Don't underestimate how quickly this can turn about.

This would require a fairly high level of stupid.   True, at the moment there is a lot of stupid around, but it seems to be fairly widely dispersed, not concentrated enough to trigger a referendumb in any one member state. Stay tuned.
Up 5%. I still think the rational choice is to not offer any plebiscite, but this makes a compelling case why it might happen anyway.
No, the UK will act as a sign for things to come for other countries considering leaving the EU. The hesitation the UK is showing will cause other countries to think twice before they leave the EU
timeframe too short, per @Zette314. GJP people, "officially announce an intention to hold" would have been a better question than "set a date" I suspect

A year is a long time in politics! Dutch and Swedish politicians are currently resisting it despite the will of their populations. The French have an election in April/May 2017 and, with the rise of the likes of the FN, it seems likely that a referendum may need to be offered to placate those voters (similar to the Conservatives in the UK, as they lost votes to UKIP). Austria needs to re-run its election after the anti-EU candidate was edged out by dodgy postal votes.

Czech seems the most likely. Spain is a distant second. Italy probably isn't democratic enough to offer a referendum, but politicians have a remote chance of doing so to rebuild the facade of a modern values.

Netherlands? France? Italy? Probably not within this timeframe. Next time, politicians will only call a referendum if there is a popular and political consensus to leave the EU. In that case, a referendum will legitimize an action that would be taken anyway. In an attempt to thwart further secessions, the EU may abandon some aspects of integration and European governance, eliminating some of the motivation for leaving.

Note that this question is "set a date". For example, in the UK it was nearly 3 years between the announcement of an intention to hold a referendum and the signing of the legislation, and then another two months after that before a date was set. Those two months could be important given the dutch and french elections in the first half of 2017, even if legislation was passed / decision taken very quickly there are logistical challenges to setting a date. So even if those elections lead to conditions where a referendum will happen, it seems unlikely to me that the date for the referendum would be set by July 1st.
Multiple countries have started talking about it
The remaining nations and their populations appear to have moved in favour of EU membership now that the consequences of the British vote are apparent.
Eastern countries have no financial interest whatsoever. So, France with LP win, or any other country for whatever unexpected reason.

Initial forecast based on "what makes sense." Since there are 28 (and lowering) political entities, the probability is probably higher. I agree that letting the citizens vote is not much of a stretch; of course the Brexit is a great example of how things can get out of control.
Cameron made such a colossal mistake, reading people and timing the referendum. Why would others rush in to do the same?
Alastaircookie is right.      Maybe AFTER July 2017 as Summer vacations will take precedence over critical thinking.

I think there is a 61% chance because they only have to set a date for a referendum before 1 July 2017. They don't have to vote leave or stay by then. Also, only one member has to do this for it to resolve to yes. Since most people are followers, it seems likely that at least one member state (which is composed of people) will set a date. The UK is a leader in voting to leave the EU, and all leaders lead by example, either a good or bad example, and followers follow examples without regard to which type they are. Just to clarify, I don't think the "results" of Brexit will matter as much as the example of having done it.
no way.  after Brexit if you're in the EU Establishment, you circle the wagons and would rather risk being voted out of office than push for, or heed the call of, a referendum.

Improbable, until more than the initial consequences of the Brexit decision are a little clearer, and also the EU's approach to negotiations with the UK. Austria and Italy may be worth watching, though, as an outside chance. Several of the most overtly EU-sceptic countries and governments are in the 2004 accession states in Central and Eastern Europe, and even though the three most sceptical of them (Poland, Hungary, Czech Rep) are yet to adopt the Euro, they would have too much to lose financially in the event they left the EU.
Without knowing the different governments' positions, I'm doubting there is another Cameron out there.

AFAIK, at this time France is the only country that has the legal framework in place to hold such a referendum, the French President has the legal authority to do so. For all the other countries 1 July 2017 is probably too soon. I don't think it is very likely that Marine Le Pen will be the next French president (the second round of the vote takes place in May). And even she may not want to act that fast.
Related movements will wait until the memory of immediate financial panic fades.
